column4: hey guys ive a prob recently my ubuntu machine doesnt detect my usb wlan adapter anymore though it used to
power use skyp e or ekiga
guys, is it the same with linux that when i use a 64bit version hardware support is worse?
Hardware support should be the same on 64-bit as on 32-bit, in general
There may be a few exceptions, but I don't know of any
i never used a 64bit linux but everybody knows thats the fact on a windows platform
That's because Windows depends on drivers written by the hardware manufacturers, and many of them haven't made 64-bit drivers for all their older products
Linux drivers are open-source and have pretty much all been ported to 64-bit by the Linux developers
ok. what about binary drivers like nvidia or flgrx
nVidia's driver has a 64-bit version that works fine (I'm using it right now) and I'm pretty sure ATI does too
alexbe01 is correct in pointing out that there's no 64-bit Flash or Java browser plugins -- that's the only really noteworthy 64-bit limitation I'm aware of
The Adobe Flash and Sun Java browser plugins are not available in 64-bit versions
are you guys seriosu? i cant use it then..
so you can't use Flash or Java applets on 64-bit Linux unless you use one of the free alternatives (like gnash for Flash, which doesn't work very well)
There's a workaround for Flash involving something called nspluginwrapper to load the 32-bit Flash plugin, but I've had mixed success with it in Debian (never tried it in Ubuntu)
there are not much reasons for me to go for 64 bit so i just forget abou that
